issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch for PersonResource between template and solution. The template defines PersonResource(PersonService personService) (single-arg constructor) while the solution defines PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey) (two-arg constructor). The problem statement refers to PersonResource but does not mention any apiKey parameter. This discrepancy is structural (different constructor signatures) and can confuse students when comparing template and solution or when trying to wire the controller with Spring. If a String parameter is present in the constructor without being bound (@Value) or provided as a bean, Spring injection may fail or require additional configuration not described in the statement, creating an implementation barrier.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signatures consistent. Either remove the extra String apiKey parameter from the solution's PersonResource constructor so it matches the template (recommended), or explicitly document and wire the apiKey (e.g., add @Value("${some.prop}") String apiKey or provide a String bean) in both template and problem description so students know it is required. Prefer removing the unused extra parameter in the solution unless there is a documented reason to inject a String.

issues.description: The solution repository's PersonResource constructor has an extra constructor parameter named 'apiKey' (public PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey)) that is not present in the template repository or mentioned in the problem statement. This introduces an identifier ('apiKey') that does not appear elsewhere in the exercise and can confuse students comparing template, problem description, and solution: they may wonder where this 'apiKey' comes from, whether they must provide/configure it, or why the constructor signatures differ between template and solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the constructor signatures across artifacts. Either remove the unused 'apiKey' parameter from the solution's PersonResource constructor so it matches the template and problem statement (public PersonResource(PersonService personService)), or (if an apiKey is intentionally required) document it in the problem statement and add the same constructor parameter / configuration to the template. Preferably, remove the extra parameter in the solution to avoid introducing an unexplained identifier.
